turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi there. It's Doctor Smith from Babylon.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>Hi Doctor Smith</UNSURE>. Hi, can you confirm your name, date of birth, and your home address please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hi Doctor Smith.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes. My name is Mary Jo. Date of birth is January first, nineteen eighty.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And my address is uh, sixty Sloane Avenue, London.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, <UNSURE>I</UNSURE>, are you in a private place where you can have a consultation today?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>Absolutely</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So, a couple of things. I, I, think I may have, overdone my workouts, and now my knees are hurting, and they're clicking a lot, and it's starting to worry me.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I can't run very far, um, any more without just feeling, pain in my knees.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And then, sometimes I also get this weird tingling in my toes. Um.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So yeah, that's, that's it. I'm just concerned and I figured you know I'd call and, see if you can, help me figure out what's going on.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>OK</UNSURE>, that's fine. So when do you think it started?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So probably, it's been about two weeks.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um, and, any joint problems before that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: You know not, not really. I mean I play a lot of sports. Um, and I had a <UNIN/>, like I play some ice hockey, and I had this injury a few months ago.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: You know I just like, fell on the ice and, and, you know had a, huge bruise but, I think that's about it.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, So, um, at the moment, just tell me about the exercise that you're doing, normally.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So I'm training, well, I'm currently training for a marathon, um, that's gonna happen in, June. And so, I'm trying to run like.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I mean right now, I'm actually not even doing such long runs, maybe like seven or eight miles. And so, I started about uh, maybe a month ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I've done like, you know, four or five miles, and I've just done like a couple of seven, mile runs.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And then uh, uh, and then you know I go to the gym like few times a week and, kinda do my, usual routine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, but, yeah, I think the only thing that's really different has, have been, the runs, the longer runs.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, have you had, any times when the knee feels like it's giving way underneath you?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, well, I, what do you mean by that? I'm not sure what, what <UNSURE>that</UNSURE> means.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So, it means if you're, if you're there and <UNSURE>uh</UNSURE>, you just feel it sort of jolt, like give way, feel unstable underneath you.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Not, not bad, I mean it just kinda starts hurting, you know. Um.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And does it hurt, uh, how far into the run does it generally hurt?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: You know I would say probably starts off like after, uh, maybe, twenty minutes or so. Which is, probably I don't know like somewhere around mile, three maybe,  two and a half or three miles.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Ooh you're fast. Um.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> switching my kilometres and miles, I'm not sure, <UNSURE>all right</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> Um. And, um, do you have to stop running, or can you run through the pain?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, that is a good question. So, um, you know the last few times, the last time I actually stopped, I mean I ran a little bit longer, but then I stopped, because it was um, I, I feel like it's getting worse.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, and, when I start doing my abs, that's, you know when I do my abs. <UNSURE>It's</UNSURE> kind of requiring me to move my you know, um, to kind of go from the flex position on my knees, and straighten my legs, then I feel all this clicking.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And, I think that's also freaked me out, and uh, I just figured you know, something's wrong <UNSURE>here</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right. And, you said before, it's both knees.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So it's more, um, it's actually my right knee that hurts.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>And</UNSURE>, any problems with your left one?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, <UNSURE>and</UNSURE>, can you just describe in the knee, or show me whereabouts the pain, is happening mainly?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So, ah, you know I, I feel it, it's kind of weird, I feel it in the middle, but I almost feel like maybe it kind of uh,  um, moves to the right, to the right of my knee a little bit.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Have you noticed any tenderness when you press over any areas in the knee?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So, yes, well it's, I have, probably some fluid. I googled it, and you know it says that sometimes <UNIN/> fluid accumulates uh, <UNSURE>I</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. <UNIN/>, does it look swollen to you?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Sorry?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Does the knee look swollen?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, well it did, like, the first time I ran, it was a little bit swollen, but then I just put some like ice on it, and it went away.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, but, right now, right now it's not swollen, and right now it doesn't hurt, you know.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, but, it just kind of comes on when uh, um, or you know right now when I flex and extend my leg, it, there's no clicking but, I'll notice it in the gym and then, you know, when I run it'll start hurting.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and, if you're sitting, still for a while, do you have any problems when you stand up, any locking up of the knee?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Can't straighten it. Any problems going up and down stairs?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any problems just walking normally?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, <UNSURE>none</UNSURE>, I don't.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And <UNSURE>intervals</UNSURE> of range of movement. Are you able to fully straighten the leg?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And what about fully flex it?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Are you taking any medication for the knee?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Well, um, since you're asking. Um, yes I <UNIN/>, I take Ibuprofen, um, and I'll just kinda, use it sometime like uh, um, like sometimes I have some joint issues, but you know, that kind of, is not very frequent. So I'll take Ibuprofen for that.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: But you know it's nothing like major maybe, like, four hundred milligrams max, something like that.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I also sometimes will um, you know, smoke a joint.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, and, yeah, other than that, that's it.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and any other joint problems, that you're getting? Any back pains? Small swelling of your, hands, feet, elbows, wrists? Any pain?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>No</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, well I have sometimes, you know how sometimes like if you stand for a long time, your feet will kinda, or your legs will swell up. Like I noticed it because of my socks, I'll just kind of, notice this indentation.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>OK</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And then, another weird thing. I've felt this just once, but there was this tingling in my toes, like uh, um, after the run.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: There was tingling in my toes like on my, you know my right toes, um, so.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: On your right <UNSURE>side</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any change in colour, or temperature of your lower legs?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any swelling which stays if you push in, and then you release it, that it stays there?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Well I don't know if I really try that, but I, I will tell you that, what I noticed is like if I, you know when my socks come off, I kind of notice that indentation a little bit, I mean it's not like major, right but, I. Uh, I mean do you mean I just need to like press and see what happens, if it like kind of stays or, <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah, any, or any pain in the back of the calf or anything like that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>No</UNSURE>, no, nothing like that, no.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and, with your foot, has that gone back to normal now? Do you feel any altered senstation, tingling numbness, anything like that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No it was just, it was that time, uh, but it was just really weird, because it kind of went on for a while.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.And any pain in the joints of your foot or <UNIN/>, on the underside in the arch? Any problems walking round on hard floors?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, have you had, any other medical problems before?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, well, I had uh.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: You know <UNSURE>what</UNSURE> just, kind of your garden variety stuff, right, colds and, uh. I mean I, I do have, I'm far-sighted, and so I had uh, I had Lasik surgery.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And then, once I had this really bad UTI, they thought it was kidney stones, and so they had me actually in ER.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And if my GP didn't call them, tell them, that you know, they don't need to give me Morphine.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, that was kind of an awful experience but, uh, other than that, you know, I'm, I'm, I'm pretty good.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, <UNSURE>and</UNSURE>, do you take any other medications, apart from the ones you told me about?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Well, I'll take uh, I take vitamin D.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I take melatonin. Sometimes, you know, just for cramps, I'll take, like, uh, um, ibuprofen, or actually <UNIN/>, uh, I'll take, what am I taking? Aleve. Whatever Aleve is.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Think that's maybe um, Acetaminophen, or, I can't remember what class of drugs.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: You know occasionally, if I'm really having hard times, like I'll, I'll sleeping, I'll take Xanax.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, but, I prefer Melatonin, it's just sometimes Melatonin doesn't work.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And, any problems with your stomach, or asthma, indigestion, acid <UNSURE>reflux</UNSURE>?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, no, no problems.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/>. <UNSURE>And</UNSURE>, what I would suggest is, definitely carrying on with the ice therapy that you've been using. So, as much as you can, 'cause that really does make a difference to injuries.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>Brings</UNSURE> the healing blood into the area, and it gives it the best chance of, getting better. So, as much as you can, use the ice.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, obviously you're trying to stick to a marathon programme, but.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, I would, try and ease up on the running, if you can. And if it, if it's painful enough that you're, having to stop running, then it's not a good idea, to do that.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um. It's fine to take the Ibuprofen. Um, I can prescribe you a slightly stronger, anti-inflammatory that you can take regularly instead of the Ibuprofen, but not with the Ibuprofen.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>Hmm</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: But make <UNSURE>sure</UNSURE> that with food. Ultimately we probably need to, examine the knee.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, so, the best thing I would, suggest, getting a appointment with the physiotherapist first, who can do like a long, assessment, and examination of the knee.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And then <UNSURE>we can</UNSURE> make an assessment as to whether we need to do any, um, imagery to <UNIN/>, have a look inside the knee, and see if there's any problem with the, cartilage.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Well, you know I read, I read some stuff online that, that maybe like my ligaments there's, I think it's like ACL or, or something like that right, and so if that. I mean I'm kind of like freaked out that <UNSURE>that</UNSURE> may break.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So do you think it's that, or?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, it's, it's not really possible to, diagnose that over the <UNIN/>, over the video. So we definitely would need to, see you. And, the, a physio is the best point of call, because they'll probably be the most likely initial treatment.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>Right</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: But certainly if the appointment time's too long to wait, then we can see, we can see you <UNSURE>in</UNSURE> our clinic as well.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Can you, so are you going to send referral for that?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yep, <UNIN/> we can, we can do a referral before that. If in the meantime you develop like persistant swelling, heat, redness, um, of the knee, or high temperature, feel unwell, or it completely locks up and you can't bend and stretch it.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>OK. Great</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Then, you'd need to see a doctor urgently, so call us back <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> in that, case. <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>That sounds</UNSURE> good. Thank you yeah. <UNIN/>, sure I mean, give me the, stronger medicine, I'll give that a try.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. I'll send it through to your pharmacy for you. OK? Thank you, bye.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>OK</UNSURE>. Sweet. Thanks so <UNSURE>much. OK</UNSURE>. Bye, bye.
